Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=19LNZIah8QwkojAckBlqMKFyaulnXVIQRsSfdMbDX-pYN2vI

David Saff wrote:

> I had promised not to post on this topic again, but I'm still genuinely 
> curious: is there not room, in your opinion, for a third option between 
> "totally public: published and documented for all the world to use in 
> safety", and "totally private: utterly hidden, technically enforced to 
> be available only to the code publisher"? 

No, I don't think there is. Sure, if you're just playing around in your 
own code base with a few people, maybe you can get away with this. 
However, API design techniques that work well amongst friends don't 
always scale to the audience size achieved by JUnit. If you're 
developing serious library software that's intended for many thousands 
of people to use, most of  whom you've never met and most of whom you 
never will, then there's no middle ground. Commit to what you're willing 
to promise, document it well, and then hide everything else.*

-- 
ï»¿Elliotte Rusty Harold  elharo@...
XML in a Nutshell 3rd Edition Just Published!
http://www.cafeconleche.org/books/xian3/
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN=0596007647/cafeaulaitA/ref=nosim

* Current versions of Java don't actually allow one to "technically 
enforce" the hiding as much as I would like. The sun packages are one 
example of things that really shouldn't be public, but need to be due to 
the limitations of the language. This may be partially addressed in Java 
7, Dolphin. And of course reflection allows you to access even the 
private parts of any class you like. But to the extent, the hiding can 
be technically enforced, it should be.
subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring
